metadata.titel_preek: Lent and Holy Week: Ash Wednesday and First Sunday in Lent

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God intervenes in the human condition of universal sin and self-deception to justify and recreate the sinner through the substitutionary death of Christ.

subject.identificatie: God (specifically in the person of Jesus Christ)
tekstueel_bewijs: God has shown us a great thing.
There is Another who has taken the sentence upon himself.
Jesus... has voluntarily taken our place.
He has wrought the salvation of his enemies.

object.identificatie: Salvation, justification, and the 'recreation' of the human person.
tekstueel_bewijs: make a completely new person out of the sinner
the reality of God, the power of God, the holiness of God, who has the absolute right to make demands and render judgments
the salvation of each and every one of us
while we were still sinners, Christ died for us
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer is explicitly positioned as the Receiver (the one at the mercy of God) rather than the Subject.

helper.identificatie: Jesus Christ (as the Mediator) and the Knowledge of Grace.
tekstueel_bewijs: The knowledge of grace has preceded the confession of sin.
Jesus... bearing in his own body the storm of the wrath of God.
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Subject who provides the Helper (Christ).
helper.rol_van_geest: Indwelling power (implied in the prayer for a 'new and contrite heart').

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin as a cosmic power, self-deception, and the 'wrath of God'.
tekstueel_bewijs: the storm of the wrath of God against sin
the line separating good and evil passes... right through every human heart
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is treated not as a mistake but as a condition that requires a 'Subject-switch' (Christ taking our place) because humans are 'helpless'.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human response of repentance and honest self-inventory.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer/Hearer
secundair_narratief_programma.object: Honest confession and 'insight' into one's own condition.
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The sermon explicitly states that the knowledge of grace (Program 1) precedes and enables the confession (Program 2).

voorbeelden_god_subject: God has shown us a great thing.
He has wrought the salvation of his enemies.
God made him to be sin.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We throw ourselves on his mercy.
We do not need to lie to ourselves.
The psalmist demonstrated that he has learned to see sin as God sees it.

voorbeelden: The person who confesses sin in this free way...
The knowledge of grace has preceded the confession.
God is truly able to do away with sin.
While we were still helpless, Christ died.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes human 'non-power' (helplessness) and God's absolute 'power' (ability) to save, shifting the burden of performance from the hearer to God.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from the tension of S2 (Judgment) to the exposure of ~S1 (Pretense), then resolves through Christ taking S2 to bring the hearer to S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Substitutionary Atonement: Christ occupies the position of the 'outcast' and 'condemned' to move the sinner to 'righteousness'.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; the 'storm of the wrath of God' is presented as a real narrative force.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. It consistently identifies God as the primary actor in salvation and treats human action (repentance) as a secondary response to a prior divine act.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: The psalmist demonstrated that he has learned to see sin as God sees it.

indicatoren_genade.indicator: God as Subject of Active Verbs
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: God made [Jesus] to be sin who knew no sin.
bearing in his own body the storm of the wrath of God against sin

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: The Psalmist is used as a model of 'insight', but this is immediately grounded in the fact that God is the one who enables this insight.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides this by stating that the Psalmist's confidence is in God's ability, not his own penitence.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the 'exhausting charade' of self-justification; psychological rest.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic leanings; salvation is entirely of God.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'searching self-inventory' of Lent to the 'substitutionary work of Christ' is seamless and logically integrated.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus, the Son of God, has voluntarily taken our place.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit is asked to 'create and make in us new and contrite hearts', implying the endowment of a competence the human lacks.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is an 'onslaught' and a 'storm' that humans cannot manage.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God as the Subject of the fundamental soteriological program. The hearer is never asked to perform the 'Object' of salvation, only to receive it.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain current balance; it serves the Lenten theme of human helplessness.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a masterclass in Rutledge's 'Grammar of Grace'. It avoids the trap of making repentance a 'work' by framing it as a response to a prior divine reality.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: A rhetorical analysis might focus on the effective use of Tolkien/Solzhenitsyn quotes; Greimas reveals that these quotes serve to strip the human Subject of its 'Savoir-faire' (moral superiority).
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis would explain the Hebrew of Psalm 51; Greimas shows how the sermon uses the Psalm to reassign the role of 'Subject' from the 'I' of the hearer to the 'He' of Christ.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas highlights that the 'Opponent' in this sermon is not just 'bad behavior' but the very act of 'drawing lines' (self-justification), which only a divine Subject can overcome.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses the 'Axis of Transmission' to move values from God to the Receiver without requiring a 'Performance' from the Receiver first.
